A timeline of the major events

December 30, 2021: David Greenberg sends an internal email

notifying Facilities staff that McShane would retire within the next

month, and that Fuchs would take over amid a search for a new VP.

January 31, 2022: McShane quietly departs.

February 1, 2022: Fuchs becomes interim VP.

In the ensuing months, both the director of finance and

administration and the executive director of CUIMC operations

resign, in part due to their relationship with Fuchs, according

to an anonymous complaint filed several months later.

September 8, 2022: Greenberg announces Gerald Lewis as the new

VP of Public Safety.

September 26, 2022: Fuchs returns to her previous role, assistant

vice president for investigations.

September 29, 2022: An anonymous complaint is filed with the

Office of University Compliance alleging Fuchs was primarily

responsible for creating a toxic workplace culture within the

department. Three days earlier, Fuchs was herself still a member of

the University compliance committee.

Mid-October: Lewis officially introduces himself to the entire

Public Safety team during a “command staff” meeting in Low

Library.

Mid-October: In an altercation on the Manhattanville campus,

Fuchs refers to someone else within the department as a “short

motherfucker” and another lower-ranking employee as a

“cockroach,” according to two people familiar with the matter.

She also made disparaging remarks about Lewis, they said.

November 17, 2022: An internal email is sent by Greenberg and

Lewis announcing Fuchs’ retirement and commending her service

to Columbia.

November 30, 2022: Bollinger, who presided over Greenberg for the

entirety of both McShane and Fuchs’ terms in Public Safety, says

in an exit interview with Spectator that the department’s leadership,

including Greenberg, is “very dedicated” and “very sensitive to the

issues we should care about.” He does not, however, mention Fuchs

or McShane.

January 1, 2023: Fuchs does not depart from the University and

instead, according to several people familiar with the matter,

transfers over to work in the Office of General Counsel, the school’s

chief legal office.

Graphic by Laya Gollamudi

A timeline of the major events

December 30, 2021: David Greenberg sends an internal email notifying facilities staff that McShane would retire within the next month, and that Fuchs would take over amid a search for a new VP.

January 31, 2022: McShane quietly departs.

February 1, 2022: Fuchs becomes interim VP.

In the ensuing months, both the director of finance and administration and the executive

director of CUIMC operations resign, in part due to their relationship with Fuchs, according

to an anonymous complaint filed several months later.

September 8, 2022: Greenberg

announces Gerald Lewis as the new VP of Public Safety.

September 26, 2022: Fuchs returns to her previous role, assistant vice president for investigations.

September 29, 2022: An anonymous complaint is filed with the Office of University Compliance alleging Fuchs was primarily responsible for creating a toxic workplace culture within the department. Three days earlier, Fuchs was herself still a member of the University compliance committee.

Mid-October: Lewis officially

introduces himself to the entire

Public Safety team during a

“command staff” meeting in Low Library.

Mid-October: In an altercation on the Manhattanville campus, Fuchs refers to someone else within the department as a “short motherfucker” and another lower-ranking employee

as a “cockroach,” according to two people familiar with the matter. She also made disparaging remarks about Lewis, they said.

November 17, 2022: An internal email is sent by Greenberg and Lewis announcing Fuchs’ retirement and commending her service to Columbia.

November 30, 2022: Bollinger, who presided over Greenberg for the entirety of both McShane and Fuchs’ terms in Public Safety, says in an exit interview with Spectator that the department’s leadership, including Greenberg, is “very dedicated” and “very sensitive to the issues we should care about.” He does not, however, mention Fuchs or McShane.

January 1, 2023: Fuchs does not depart from the University and instead, according to several people familiar with the matter, transfers over to work in the Office of General Counsel, the school’s chief legal office.
